ImageId.documentation: The ID of the AMI used to launch the instance.

PrivateDnsName.documentation: The private DNS name assigned to the instance. This DNS name can only be used inside the Amazon EC2 network. This name is not available until the instance enters the running state. For EC2-VPC, this name is only available if you've enabled DNS hostnames for your VPC.

PublicDnsName.documentation: The public DNS name assigned to the instance. This name is not available until the instance enters the running state. For EC2-VPC, this name is only available if you've enabled DNS hostnames for your VPC.

StateTransitionReason.documentation: The reason for the most recent state transition. This might be an empty string.

KeyName.documentation: The name of the key pair, if this instance was launched with an associated key pair.

AmiLaunchIndex.documentation: The AMI launch index, which can be used to find this instance in the launch group.

ProductCodes.documentation: The product codes attached to this instance, if applicable.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

Placement.documentation: The location where the instance launched, if applicable.

KernelId.documentation: The kernel associated with this instance, if applicable.

RamdiskId.documentation: The RAM disk associated with this instance, if applicable.

Platform.documentation: The value is Windows for Windows instances; otherwise blank.

SubnetId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The ID of the subnet in which the instance is running.

VpcId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The ID of the VPC in which the instance is running.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The private IP address assigned to the instance.

PublicIpAddress.documentation: The public IP address assigned to the instance, if applicable.

StateReason.documentation: The reason for the most recent state transition.

RootDeviceType.documentation: The root device type used by the AMI. The AMI can use an EBS volume or an instance store volume.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: Any block device mapping entries for the instance.

InstanceLifecycle.documentation: Indicates whether this is a Spot instance or a Scheduled Instance.

SpotInstanceRequestId.documentation: If the request is a Spot instance request, the ID of the request.

ClientToken.documentation: The idempotency token you provided when you launched the instance, if applicable.

SecurityGroups.documentation: One or more security groups for the instance.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Specifies whether to enable an instance launched in a VPC to perform NAT. This controls whether source/destination checking is enabled on the instance. A value of true means checking is enabled, and false means checking is disabled. The value must be false for the instance to perform NAT. For more information, see NAT Instances in the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide.

NetworkInterfaces.documentation: [EC2-VPC] One or more network interfaces for the instance.

IamInstanceProfile.documentation: The IAM instance profile associated with the instance, if applicable.

EbsOptimized.documentation: Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

SriovNetSupport.documentation: Specifies whether enhanced networking with the Intel 82599 Virtual Function interface is enabled.

EnaSupport.documentation: Specifies whether enhanced networking with ENA is enabled.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

DisableApiTermination.documentation: If the value is true, you can't terminate the instance through the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API; otherwise, you can.

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation: Indicates whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

RootDeviceName.documentation: The name of the root device (for example, /dev/sda1 or /dev/xvda).

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: The block device mapping of the instance.

EbsOptimized.documentation: Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O.

SriovNetSupport.documentation: Indicates whether enhanced networking with the Intel 82599 Virtual Function interface is enabled.

EnaSupport.documentation: Indicates whether enhanced networking with ENA is enabled.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Indicates whether source/destination checking is enabled. A value of true means checking is enabled, and false means checking is disabled. This value must be false for a NAT instance to perform NAT.

Groups.documentation: The security groups associated with the instance.

DeviceName.documentation: The device name exposed to the instance (for example, /dev/sdh or xvdh).

Ebs.documentation: Parameters used to automatically set up EBS volumes when the instance is launched.

DeviceName.documentation: The device name exposed to the instance (for example, /dev/sdh or xvdh).

Ebs.documentation: Parameters used to automatically set up EBS volumes when the instance is launched.

NoDevice.documentation: suppress the specified device included in the block device mapping.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type size supported by the Dedicated Host.

AvailableCapacity.documentation: The number of instances that can still be launched onto the Dedicated Host.

TotalCapacity.documentation: The total number of instances that can be launched onto the Dedicated Host.

InstanceCapacity.documentation: Information about the instance type that the Dedicated Host supports.

State.documentation: The states of the listed Reserved Instances.

InstanceCount.documentation: The number of listed Reserved Instances in the state specified by the state.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of the resource being exported.

InstanceMonitoring.documentation: Describes the monitoring information of the instance.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet.

OwnerId.documentation: The ID of the AWS account that created the network interface.

Status.documentation: The status of the network interface.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The IP address of the network interface within the subnet.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Indicates whether to validate network traffic to or from this network interface.

Association.documentation: The association information for an Elastic IP associated with the network interface.

PrivateIpAddresses.documentation: The private IP addresses associated with the network interface.

PublicIp.documentation: The public IP address or Elastic IP address bound to the network interface.

IpOwnerId.documentation: The ID of the owner of the Elastic IP address.

InstanceNetworkInterfaceAssociation.documentation: Describes association information for an Elastic IP address.

AttachmentId.documentation: The ID of the network interface attachment.

DeviceIndex.documentation: The index of the device on the instance for the network interface attachment.

Status.documentation: The attachment state.

AttachTime.documentation: The time stamp when the attachment initiated.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the network interface is deleted when the instance is terminated.

DeviceIndex.documentation: The index of the device on the instance for the network interface attachment. If you are specifying a network interface in a RunInstances request, you must provide the device index.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet associated with the network string. Applies only if creating a network interface when launching an instance.

Description.documentation: The description of the network interface. Applies only if creating a network interface when launching an instance.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The private IP address of the network interface. Applies only if creating a network interface when launching an instance.

Groups.documentation: The IDs of the security groups for the network interface. Applies only if creating a network interface when launching an instance.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: If set to true, the interface is deleted when the instance is terminated. You can specify true only if creating a new network interface when launching an instance.

PrivateIpAddresses.documentation: One or more private IP addresses to assign to the network interface. Only one private IP address can be designated as primary.

SecondaryPrivateIpAddressCount.documentation: The number of secondary private IP addresses. You can't specify this option and specify more than one private IP address using the private IP addresses option.

AssociatePublicIpAddress.documentation: Indicates whether to assign a public IP address to an instance you launch in a VPC. The public IP address can only be assigned to a network interface for eth0, and can only be assigned to a new network interface, not an existing one. You cannot specify more than one network interface in the request. If launching into a default subnet, the default value is true.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The private IP address of the network interface.

Primary.documentation: Indicates whether this IP address is the primary private IP address of the network interface.

Association.documentation: The association information for an Elastic IP address for the network interface.

Code.documentation:
The low byte represents the state. The high byte is an opaque internal value and should be ignored.

  • 0 : pending

  • 16 : running

  • 32 : shutting-down

  • 48 : terminated

  • 64 : stopping

  • 80 : stopped

InstanceState.documentation: Describes the current state of the instance.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone of the instance.

Events.documentation: Any scheduled events associated with the instance.

InstanceState.documentation: The intended state of the instance. DescribeInstanceStatus requires that an instance be in the running state.

SystemStatus.documentation: Reports impaired functionality that stems from issues related to the systems that support an instance, such as hardware failures and network connectivity problems.

InstanceStatus.documentation: Reports impaired functionality that stems from issues internal to the instance, such as impaired reachability.

Status.documentation: The status.

ImpairedSince.documentation: The time when a status check failed. For an instance that was launched and impaired, this is the time when the instance was launched.

Description.documentation:
A description of the event.

After a scheduled event is completed, it can still be described for up to a week. If the event has been completed, this description starts with the following text: [Completed].

NotBefore.documentation: The earliest scheduled start time for the event.

NotAfter.documentation: The latest scheduled end time for the event.

InstanceStatusEvent.documentation: Describes a scheduled event for an instance.

Status.documentation: The status.

Details.documentation: The system instance health or application instance health.

Attachments.documentation: Any VPCs attached to the Internet gateway.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the Internet gateway.

InternetGatewayAttachment.documentation: Describes the attachment of a VPC to an Internet gateway.

IpProtocol.documentation:
The IP protocol name (for tcp, udp, and icmp) or number (see Protocol Numbers).

[EC2-VPC only] When you authorize or revoke security group rules, you can use -1 to specify all.

FromPort.documentation: The start of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP type number. A value of -1 indicates all ICMP types.

ToPort.documentation: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP code. A value of -1 indicates all ICMP codes for the specified ICMP type.

UserIdGroupPairs.documentation: One or more security group and AWS account ID pairs.

PrefixListIds.documentation: (Valid for AuthorizeSecurityGroupEgress, RevokeSecurityGroupEgress and DescribeSecurityGroups only) One or more prefix list IDs for an AWS service. In an AuthorizeSecurityGroupEgress request, this is the AWS service that you want to access through a VPC endpoint from instances associated with the security group.

CidrIp.documentation: The CIDR range. You can either specify a CIDR range or a source security group, not both.

KeyFingerprint.documentation: The SHA-1 digest of the DER encoded private key.

KeyMaterial.documentation: An unencrypted PEM encoded RSA private key.

KeyFingerprint.documentation: If you used CreateKeyPair to create the key pair, this is the SHA-1 digest of the DER encoded private key. If you used ImportKeyPair to provide AWS the public key, this is the MD5 public key fingerprint as specified in section 4 of RFC4716.

Add.documentation: The AWS account ID to add to the list of launch permissions for the AMI.

Remove.documentation: The AWS account ID to remove from the list of launch permissions for the AMI.

SecurityGroups.documentation: One or more security groups. When requesting instances in a VPC, you must specify the IDs of the security groups. When requesting instances in EC2-Classic, you can specify the names or the IDs of the security groups.

UserData.documentation: The user data to make available to the instances. If you are using an AWS SDK or command line tool, Base64-encoding is performed for you, and you can load the text from a file. Otherwise, you must provide Base64-encoded text.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation:
One or more block device mapping entries.

Although you can specify encrypted EBS volumes in this block device mapping for your Spot Instances, these volumes are not encrypted.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instance.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

Default: false

LaunchSpecification.documentation: Describes the launch specification for an instance.

HostIds.documentation: The host IDs of the Dedicated Hosts you want to modify.

AutoPlacement.documentation: Specify whether to enable or disable auto-placement.

Successful.documentation: The IDs of the Dedicated Hosts that were successfully modified.

Unsuccessful.documentation: The IDs of the Dedicated Hosts that could not be modified. Check whether the setting you requested can be used.

UseLongIds.documentation: Indicate whether the resource should use longer IDs (17-character IDs).
Indicates whether the resource should use longer IDs (17-character IDs)

PrincipalArn.documentation: The ARN of the principal, which can be an IAM user, IAM role, or the root user. Specify all to modify the ID format for all IAM users, IAM roles, and the root user of the account.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Attribute.documentation: The name of the attribute to modify.

UserIds.documentation: One or more AWS account IDs. This is only valid when modifying the launchPermission attribute.

UserGroups.documentation: One or more user groups. This is only valid when modifying the launchPermission attribute.

ProductCodes.documentation: One or more product codes. After you add a product code to an AMI, it can't be removed. This is only valid when modifying the productCodes attribute.

Value.documentation: The value of the attribute being modified. This is only valid when modifying the description attribute.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Value.documentation: A new value for the attribute. Use only with the kernel, ramdisk, userData, disableApiTermination, or instanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior attribute.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation:
Modifies the DeleteOnTermination attribute for volumes that are currently attached. The volume must be owned by the caller. If no value is specified for DeleteOnTermination, the default is true and the volume is deleted when the instance is terminated.

To add instance store volumes to an Amazon EBS-backed instance, you must add them when you launch the instance. For more information, see Updating the Block Device Mapping when Launching an Instance in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Specifies whether source/destination checking is enabled. A value of true means that checking is enabled, and false means checking is disabled. This value must be false for a NAT instance to perform NAT.

DisableApiTermination.documentation: If the value is true, you can't terminate the instance using the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API; otherwise, you can. You cannot use this paramater for Spot Instances.

InstanceType.documentation: Changes the instance type to the specified value. For more information, see Instance Types. If the instance type is not valid, the error returned is InvalidInstanceAttributeValue.

Kernel.documentation: Changes the instance's kernel to the specified value. We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB.

Ramdisk.documentation: Changes the instance's RAM disk to the specified value. We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB.

UserData.documentation: Changes the instance's user data to the specified value. If you are using an AWS SDK or command line tool, Base64-encoding is performed for you, and you can load the text from a file. Otherwise, you must provide Base64-encoded text.

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation: Specifies whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

Groups.documentation: [EC2-VPC] Changes the security groups of the instance. You must specify at least one security group, even if it's just the default security group for the VPC. You must specify the security group ID, not the security group name.

EbsOptimized.documentation: Specifies whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

SriovNetSupport.documentation:
Set to simple to enable enhanced networking with the Intel 82599 Virtual Function interface for the instance.

There is no way to disable enhanced networking with the Intel 82599 Virtual Function interface at this time.

This option is supported only for HVM instances. Specifying this option with a PV instance can make it unreachable.

EnaSupport.documentation:
Set to true to enable enhanced networking with ENA for the instance.

This option is supported only for HVM instances. Specifying this option with a PV instance can make it unreachable.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of the instance that you are modifying.

Tenancy.documentation: The tenancy of the instance that you are modifying.

Affinity.documentation: The new affinity setting for the instance.

HostId.documentation: The ID of the Dedicated Host that the instance will have affinity with.

Return.documentation: Is true if the request succeeds, and an error otherwise.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Indicates whether source/destination checking is enabled. A value of true means checking is enabled, and false means checking is disabled. This value must be false for a NAT instance to perform NAT. For more information, see NAT Instances in the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide.

Groups.documentation: Changes the security groups for the network interface. The new set of groups you specify replaces the current set. You must specify at least one group, even if it's just the default security group in the VPC. You must specify the ID of the security group, not the name.

Attachment.documentation: Information about the interface attachment. If modifying the 'delete on termination' attribute, you must specify the ID of the interface attachment.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive token you provide to ensure idempotency of your modification request. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

ReservedInstancesIds.documentation: The IDs of the Reserved Instances to modify.

TargetConfigurations.documentation: The configuration settings for the Reserved Instances to modify.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Attribute.documentation:
The snapshot attribute to modify.

Only volume creation permissions may be modified at the customer level.

OperationType.documentation: The type of operation to perform to the attribute.

UserIds.documentation: The account ID to modify for the snapshot.

GroupNames.documentation: The group to modify for the snapshot.

CreateVolumePermission.documentation: A JSON representation of the snapshot attribute modification.

SpotFleetRequestId.documentation: The ID of the Spot fleet request.

ExcessCapacityTerminationPolicy.documentation: Indicates whether running Spot instances should be terminated if the target capacity of the Spot fleet request is decreased below the current size of the Spot fleet.

Return.documentation: Is true if the request succeeds, and an error otherwise.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet.

MapPublicIpOnLaunch.documentation: Specify true to indicate that instances launched into the specified subnet should be assigned public IP address.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

AutoEnableIO.documentation: Indicates whether the volume should be auto-enabled for I/O operations.

EnableDnsSupport.documentation:
Indicates whether the DNS resolution is supported for the VPC. If enabled, queries to the Amazon provided DNS server at the 169.254.169.253 IP address, or the reserved IP address at the base of the VPC network range "plus two" will succeed. If disabled, the Amazon provided DNS service in the VPC that resolves public DNS hostnames to IP addresses is not enabled.

You cannot modify the DNS resolution and DNS hostnames attributes in the same request. Use separate requests for each attribute.

EnableDnsHostnames.documentation:
Indicates whether the instances launched in the VPC get DNS hostnames. If enabled, instances in the VPC get DNS hostnames; otherwise, they do not.

You cannot modify the DNS resolution and DNS hostnames attributes in the same request. Use separate requests for each attribute. You can only enable DNS hostnames if you've enabled DNS support.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

ResetPolicy.documentation: Specify true to reset the policy document to the default policy. The default policy allows access to the service.

PolicyDocument.documentation: A policy document to attach to the endpoint. The policy must be in valid JSON format.

AddRouteTableIds.documentation: One or more route tables IDs to associate with the endpoint.

RemoveRouteTableIds.documentation: One or more route table IDs to disassociate from the endpoint.

Return.documentation: Returns true if the request succeeds; otherwise, it returns an error.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the operation, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of the VPC peering connection.

RequesterPeeringConnectionOptions.documentation: The VPC peering connection options for the requester VPC.

AccepterPeeringConnectionOptions.documentation: The VPC peering connection options for the accepter VPC.

RequesterPeeringConnectionOptions.documentation: Information about the VPC peering connection options for the requester VPC.

AccepterPeeringConnectionOptions.documentation: Information about the VPC peering connection options for the accepter VPC.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

InstanceMonitorings.documentation: Monitoring information for one or more instances.

State.documentation: Indicates whether monitoring is enabled for the instance.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

AllocationId.documentation: The allocation ID for the Elastic IP address.

Status.documentation: The status of the move of the IP address.

MoveStatus.documentation: The status of the Elastic IP address that's being moved to the EC2-VPC platform, or restored to the EC2-Classic platform.

MovingAddressStatus.documentation: Describes the status of a moving Elastic IP address.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC in which the NAT gateway is located.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which the NAT gateway is located.

CreateTime.documentation: The date and time the NAT gateway was created.

DeleteTime.documentation: The date and time the NAT gateway was deleted, if applicable.

NatGatewayAddresses.documentation: Information about the IP addresses and network interface associated with the NAT gateway.

State.documentation:
The state of the NAT gateway.

  • pending: The NAT gateway is being created and is not ready to process traffic.

  • failed: The NAT gateway could not be created. Check the failureCode and failureMessage fields for the reason.

  • available: The NAT gateway is able to process traffic. This status remains until you delete the NAT gateway, and does not indicate the health of the NAT gateway.

  • deleting: The NAT gateway is in the process of being terminated and may still be processing traffic.

  • deleted: The NAT gateway has been terminated and is no longer processing traffic.

FailureCode.documentation: If the NAT gateway could not be created, specifies the error code for the failure. (InsufficientFreeAddressesInSubnet | Gateway.NotAttached | InvalidAllocationID.NotFound | Resource.AlreadyAssociated | InternalError | InvalidSubnetID.NotFound)

FailureMessage.documentation:
If the NAT gateway could not be created, specifies the error message for the failure, that corresponds to the error code.

  • For InsufficientFreeAddressesInSubnet: "Subnet has insufficient free addresses to create this NAT gateway"

  • For Gateway.NotAttached: "Network vpc-xxxxxxxx has no Internet gateway attached"

  • For InvalidAllocationID.NotFound: "Elastic IP address eipalloc-xxxxxxxx could not be associated with this NAT gateway"

  • For Resource.AlreadyAssociated: "Elastic IP address eipalloc-xxxxxxxx is already associated"

  • For InternalError: "Network interface eni-xxxxxxxx, created and used internally by this NAT gateway is in an invalid state. Please try again."

  • For InvalidSubnetID.NotFound: "The specified subnet subnet-xxxxxxxx does not exist or could not be found."

ProvisionedBandwidth.documentation: Reserved. If you need to sustain traffic greater than the documented limits, contact us through the Support Center.

PublicIp.documentation: The Elastic IP address associated with the NAT gateway.

AllocationId.documentation: The allocation ID of the Elastic IP address that's associated with the NAT gateway.

PrivateIp.documentation: The private IP address associated with the Elastic IP address.

NetworkInterfaceId.documentation: The ID of the network interface associated with the NAT gateway.

NatGatewayAddress.documentation: Describes the IP addresses and network interface associated with a NAT gateway.

Active.documentation:
The current price schedule, as determined by the term remaining for the Reserved Instance in the listing.

A specific price schedule is always in effect, but only one price schedule can be active at any time. Take, for example, a Reserved Instance listing that has five months remaining in its term. When you specify price schedules for five months and two months, this means that schedule 1, covering the first three months of the remaining term, will be active during months 5, 4, and 3. Then schedule 2, covering the last two months of the term, will be active for months 2 and 1.

SriovNetSupport.documentation:
Set to simple to enable enhanced networking with the Intel 82599 Virtual Function interface for the AMI and any instances that you launch from the AMI.

There is no way to disable sriovNetSupport at this time.

This option is supported only for HVM AMIs. Specifying this option with a PV AMI can make instances launched from the AMI unreachable.

EnaSupport.documentation:
Set to true to enable enhanced networking with ENA for the AMI and any instances that you launch from the AMI.

This option is supported only for HVM AMIs. Specifying this option with a PV AMI can make instances launched from the AMI unreachable.

ReasonCodes.documentation:
One or more reason codes that describes the health state of your instance.

  • instance-stuck-in-state: My instance is stuck in a state.

  • unresponsive: My instance is unresponsive.

  • not-accepting-credentials: My instance is not accepting my credentials.

  • password-not-available: A password is not available for my instance.

  • performance-network: My instance is experiencing performance problems which I believe are network related.

  • performance-instance-store: My instance is experiencing performance problems which I believe are related to the instance stores.

  • performance-ebs-volume: My instance is experiencing performance problems which I believe are related to an EBS volume.

  • performance-other: My instance is experiencing performance problems.

  • other: [explain using the description parameter]

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum hourly price (bid) for any Spot instance launched to fulfill the request.

ClientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. For more information, see How to Ensure Idempotency in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

InstanceCount.documentation:
The maximum number of Spot instances to launch.

Default: 1

ValidFrom.documentation:
The start date of the request. If this is a one-time request, the request becomes active at this date and time and remains active until all instances launch, the request expires, or the request is canceled. If the request is persistent, the request becomes active at this date and time and remains active until it expires or is canceled.

Default: The request is effective indefinitely.

ValidUntil.documentation:
The end date of the request. If this is a one-time request, the request remains active until all instances launch, the request is canceled, or this date is reached. If the request is persistent, it remains active until it is canceled or this date and time is reached.

Default: The request is effective indefinitely.

LaunchGroup.documentation:
The instance launch group. Launch groups are Spot instances that launch together and terminate together.

Default: Instances are launched and terminated individually

AvailabilityZoneGroup.documentation:
The user-specified name for a logical grouping of bids.

When you specify an Availability Zone group in a Spot Instance request, all Spot instances in the request are launched in the same Availability Zone. Instance proximity is maintained with this parameter, but the choice of Availability Zone is not. The group applies only to bids for Spot Instances of the same instance type. Any additional Spot instance requests that are specified with the same Availability Zone group name are launched in that same Availability Zone, as long as at least one instance from the group is still active.

If there is no active instance running in the Availability Zone group that you specify for a new Spot instance request (all instances are terminated, the bid is expired, or the bid falls below current market), then Amazon EC2 launches the instance in any Availability Zone where the constraint can be met. Consequently, the subsequent set of Spot instances could be placed in a different zone from the original request, even if you specified the same Availability Zone group.

Default: Instances are launched in any available Availability Zone.

BlockDurationMinutes.documentation:
The required duration for the Spot instances (also known as Spot blocks), in minutes. This value must be a multiple of 60 (60, 120, 180, 240, 300, or 360).

The duration period starts as soon as your Spot instance receives its instance ID. At the end of the duration period, Amazon EC2 marks the Spot instance for termination and provides a Spot instance termination notice, which gives the instance a two-minute warning before it terminates.

Note that you can't specify an Availability Zone group or a launch group if you specify a duration.

UserData.documentation: The user data to make available to the instances. If you are using an AWS SDK or command line tool, Base64-encoding is performed for you, and you can load the text from a file. Otherwise, you must provide Base64-encoded text.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation:
One or more block device mapping entries.

Although you can specify encrypted EBS volumes in this block device mapping for your Spot Instances, these volumes are not encrypted.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instance.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

Default: false

You can't specify this parameter in combination with the following parameters: the CIDR IP address range, the start of the port range, the IP protocol, and the end of the port range. For EC2-VPC, the source security group must be in the same VPC. To revoke a specific rule for an IP protocol and port range, use a set of IP permissions instead.

You can't specify this parameter in combination with the following parameters: the CIDR IP address range, the IP protocol, the start of the port range, and the end of the port range. To revoke a specific rule for an IP protocol and port range, use a set of IP permissions instead.

ToPort.documentation: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP code number. For the ICMP code number, use -1 to specify all ICMP codes for the ICMP type.

Constraints: Between 1 and the maximum number you're allowed for the specified instance type. For more information about the default limits, and how to request an increase, see How many instances can I run in Amazon EC2 in the Amazon EC2 General FAQ.

MaxCount.documentation:
The maximum number of instances to launch. If you specify more instances than Amazon EC2 can launch in the target Availability Zone, Amazon EC2 launches the largest possible number of instances above MinCount.

Constraints: Between 1 and the maximum number you're allowed for the specified instance type. For more information about the default limits, and how to request an increase, see How many instances can I run in Amazon EC2 in the Amazon EC2 FAQ.

KeyName.documentation:
The name of the key pair. You can create a key pair using CreateKeyPair or ImportKeyPair.

If you do not specify a key pair, you can't connect to the instance unless you choose an AMI that is configured to allow users another way to log in.

SecurityGroups.documentation:
[EC2-Classic, default VPC] One or more security group names. For a nondefault VPC, you must use security group IDs instead.

Default: Amazon EC2 uses the default security group.

SecurityGroupIds.documentation:
One or more security group IDs. You can create a security group using CreateSecurityGroup.

Default: Amazon EC2 uses the default security group.

UserData.documentation: The user data to make available to the instance. For more information, see Running Commands on Your Linux Instance at Launch (Linux) and Adding User Data (Windows). If you are using an AWS SDK or command line tool, Base64-encoding is performed for you, and you can load the text from a file. Otherwise, you must provide Base64-encoded text.

InstanceType.documentation:
The instance type. For more information, see Instance Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

Default: m1.small

KernelId.documentation:
The ID of the kernel.

We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

RamdiskId.documentation:
The ID of the RAM disk.

We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation:
The block device mapping.

Supplying both a snapshot ID and an encryption value as arguments for block-device mapping results in an error. This is because only blank volumes can be encrypted on start, and these are not created from a snapshot. If a snapshot is the basis for the volume, it contains data by definition and its encryption status cannot be changed using this action.

SubnetId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The ID of the subnet to launch the instance into.

DisableApiTermination.documentation:
If you set this parameter to true, you can't terminate the instance using the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API; otherwise, you can. If you set this parameter to true and then later want to be able to terminate the instance, you must first change the value of the disableApiTermination attribute to false using ModifyInstanceAttribute. Alternatively, if you set InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior to terminate, you can terminate the instance by running the shutdown command from the instance.

Default: false

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation:
Indicates whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

Default: stop

PrivateIpAddress.documentation:
[EC2-VPC] The primary IP address. You must specify a value from the IP address range of the subnet.

Only one private IP address can be designated as primary. Therefore, you can't specify this parameter if PrivateIpAddresses.n.Primary is set to true and PrivateIpAddresses.n.PrivateIpAddress is set to an IP address.

Default: We select an IP address from the IP address range of the subnet.

ClientToken.documentation:
Unique, case-sensitive identifier you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

Constraints: Maximum 64 ASCII characters

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS-optimized instance.

Default: false

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

ClientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that ensures the idempotency of the request. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

LaunchSpecification.documentation: The launch specification. You must match the instance type, Availability Zone, network, and platform of the schedule that you purchased.

InstanceIdSet.documentation: The IDs of the newly launched instances.

Bucket.documentation: The bucket in which to store the AMI. You can specify a bucket that you already own or a new bucket that Amazon EC2 creates on your behalf. If you specify a bucket that belongs to someone else, Amazon EC2 returns an error.

Prefix.documentation: The beginning of the file name of the AMI.

AWSAccessKeyId.documentation: The access key ID of the owner of the bucket. Before you specify a value for your access key ID, review and follow the guidance in Best Practices for Managing AWS Access Keys.

UploadPolicy.documentation: An Amazon S3 upload policy that gives Amazon EC2 permission to upload items into Amazon S3 on your behalf.

S3Storage.documentation: Describes the storage parameters for S3 and S3 buckets for an instance store-backed AMI.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone.

SlotDurationInHours.documentation: The number of hours in the schedule.

PreviousSlotEndTime.documentation: The time that the previous schedule ended or will end.

NextSlotStartTime.documentation: The time for the next schedule to start.

HourlyPrice.documentation: The hourly price for a single instance.

TotalScheduledInstanceHours.documentation: The total number of hours for a single instance for the entire term.

TermStartDate.documentation: The start date for the Scheduled Instance.

TermEndDate.documentation: The end date for the Scheduled Instance.

CreateDate.documentation: The date when the Scheduled Instance was purchased.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type. You can specify one of the C3, C4, M4, or R3 instance types.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone.

PurchaseToken.documentation: The purchase token. This token expires in two hours.

SlotDurationInHours.documentation: The number of hours in the schedule.

FirstSlotStartTime.documentation: The time period for the first schedule to start.

HourlyPrice.documentation: The hourly price for a single instance.

TotalScheduledInstanceHours.documentation: The total number of hours for a single instance for the entire term.

MinTermDurationInDays.documentation: The minimum term. The only possible value is 365 days.

MaxTermDurationInDays.documentation: The maximum term. The only possible value is 365 days.

ScheduledInstanceAvailability.documentation: Describes a schedule that is available for your Scheduled Instances.

Interval.documentation: The interval quantity. The interval unit depends on the value of frequency. For example, every 2 weeks or every 2 months.

OccurrenceDaySet.documentation: The days. For a monthly schedule, this is one or more days of the month (1-31). For a weekly schedule, this is one or more days of the week (1-7, where 1 is Sunday).

OccurrenceRelativeToEnd.documentation: Indicates whether the occurrence is relative to the end of the specified week or month.

ScheduledInstanceRecurrence.documentation: Describes the recurring schedule for a Scheduled Instance.

Interval.documentation: The interval quantity. The interval unit depends on the value of Frequency. For example, every 2 weeks or every 2 months.

OccurrenceDays.documentation: The days. For a monthly schedule, this is one or more days of the month (1-31). For a weekly schedule, this is one or more days of the week (1-7, where 1 is Sunday). You can't specify this value with a daily schedule. If the occurrence is relative to the end of the month, you can specify only a single day.

OccurrenceRelativeToEnd.documentation: Indicates whether the occurrence is relative to the end of the specified week or month. You can't specify this value with a daily schedule.

OccurrenceUnit.documentation: The unit for OccurrenceDays (DayOfWeek or DayOfMonth). This value is required for a monthly schedule. You can't specify DayOfWeek with a weekly schedule. You can't specify this value with a daily schedule.

ScheduledInstanceRecurrenceRequest.documentation: Describes the recurring schedule for a Scheduled Instance.

DeviceName.documentation: The device name exposed to the instance (for example, /dev/sdh or xvdh).

NoDevice.documentation: Suppresses the specified device included in the block device mapping of the AMI.

VirtualName.documentation:
The virtual device name (ephemeralN). Instance store volumes are numbered starting from 0. An instance type with two available instance store volumes can specify mappings for ephemeral0 and ephemeral1.The number of available instance store volumes depends on the instance type. After you connect to the instance, you must mount the volume.

Constraints: For M3 instances, you must specify instance store volumes in the block device mapping for the instance. When you launch an M3 instance, we ignore any instance store volumes specified in the block device mapping for the AMI.

Ebs.documentation: Parameters used to set up EBS volumes automatically when the instance is launched.

ScheduledInstancesBlockDeviceMapping.documentation: Describes a block device mapping for a Scheduled Instance.

VolumeSize.documentation:
The size of the volume, in GiB.

Default: If you're creating the volume from a snapshot and don't specify a volume size, the default is the snapshot size.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the volume is deleted on instance termination.

VolumeType.documentation:
The volume type. gp2 for General Purpose SSD, io1 for Provisioned IOPS SSD, Throughput Optimized HDD for st1, Cold HDD for sc1, or standard for Magnetic.

Default: standard

Iops.documentation:
The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) that the volume supports. For io1 volumes, this represents the number of IOPS that are provisioned for the volume. For gp2 volumes, this represents the baseline performance of the volume and the rate at which the volume accumulates I/O credits for bursting. For more information about gp2 baseline performance, I/O credits, and bursting, see Amazon EBS Volume Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

Constraint: Range is 100-20000 IOPS for io1 volumes and 100-10000 IOPS for gp2 volumes.

Condition: This parameter is required for requests to create io1volumes; it is not used in requests to create gp2, st1, sc1, or standard volumes.

Encrypted.documentation: Indicates whether the volume is encrypted. You can attached encrypted volumes only to instances that support them.

ScheduledInstancesEbs.documentation: Describes an EBS volume for a Scheduled Instance.

ScheduledInstancesIamInstanceProfile.documentation: Describes an IAM instance profile for a Scheduled Instance.

ImageId.documentation: The ID of the Amazon Machine Image (AMI).

SecurityGroupIds.documentation: The IDs of one or more security groups.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: One or more block device mapping entries.

Monitoring.documentation: Enable or disable monitoring for the instances.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instances.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instances are optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS-optimized instance.

Default: false

ScheduledInstancesLaunchSpecification.documentation:
Describes the launch specification for a Scheduled Instance.

If you are launching the Scheduled Instance in EC2-VPC, you must specify the ID of the subnet. You can specify the subnet using either SubnetId or NetworkInterface.

ScheduledInstancesMonitoring.documentation: Describes whether monitoring is enabled for a Scheduled Instance.

DeviceIndex.documentation: The index of the device for the network interface attachment.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The IP address of the network interface within the subnet.

SecondaryPrivateIpAddressCount.documentation: The number of secondary private IP addresses.

AssociatePublicIpAddress.documentation: Indicates whether to assign a public IP address to instances launched in a VPC. The public IP address can only be assigned to a network interface for eth0, and can only be assigned to a new network interface, not an existing one. You cannot specify more than one network interface in the request. If launching into a default subnet, the default value is true.

Groups.documentation: The IDs of one or more security groups.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether to delete the interface when the instance is terminated.

ScheduledInstancesNetworkInterface.documentation: Describes a network interface for a Scheduled Instance.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone.

ScheduledInstancesPlacement.documentation: Describes the placement for a Scheduled Instance.

Primary.documentation: Indicates whether this is a primary IP address. Otherwise, this is a secondary IP address.

ScheduledInstancesPrivateIpAddressConfig.documentation: Describes a private IP address for a Scheduled Instance.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the owner of the security group.

IpPermissions.documentation: One or more inbound rules associated with the security group.

IpPermissionsEgress.documentation: [EC2-VPC] One or more outbound rules associated with the security group.

VpcId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The ID of the VPC for the security group.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the security group.

ReferencingVpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC with the referencing security group.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of the VPC peering connection.

SecurityGroupReference.documentation: Describes a VPC with a security group that references your security group.

EarliestTime.documentation: The earliest date and time, in UTC, for the Scheduled Instance to start.

LatestTime.documentation: The latest date and time, in UTC, for the Scheduled Instance to start. This value must be later than or equal to the earliest date and at most three months in the future.

SlotDateTimeRangeRequest.documentation: Describes the time period for a Scheduled Instance to start its first schedule. The time period must span less than one day.

EarliestTime.documentation: The earliest date and time, in UTC, for the Scheduled Instance to start.

LatestTime.documentation: The latest date and time, in UTC, for the Scheduled Instance to start.

SlotStartTimeRangeRequest.documentation: Describes the time period for a Scheduled Instance to start its first schedule.

SnapshotId.documentation: The ID of the snapshot. Each snapshot receives a unique identifier when it is created.

VolumeId.documentation: The ID of the volume that was used to create the snapshot. Snapshots created by the CopySnapshot action have an arbitrary volume ID that should not be used for any purpose.

StateMessage.documentation: Encrypted Amazon EBS snapshots are copied asynchronously. If a snapshot copy operation fails (for example, if the proper AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) permissions are not obtained) this field displays error state details to help you diagnose why the error occurred. This parameter is only returned by the DescribeSnapshots API operation.

StartTime.documentation: The time stamp when the snapshot was initiated.

Progress.documentation: The progress of the snapshot, as a percentage.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the EBS snapshot owner.

VolumeSize.documentation: The size of the volume, in GiB.

OwnerAlias.documentation: Value from an Amazon-maintained list (amazon | aws-marketplace | microsoft) of snapshot owners. Not to be confused with the user-configured AWS account alias, which is set from the IAM console.

KmsKeyId.documentation: The full ARN of the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) that was used to protect the volume encryption key for the parent volume.

DataEncryptionKeyId.documentation: The data encryption key identifier for the snapshot. This value is a unique identifier that corresponds to the data encryption key that was used to encrypt the original volume or snapshot copy. Because data encryption keys are inherited by volumes created from snapshots, and vice versa, if snapshots share the same data encryption key identifier, then they belong to the same volume/snapshot lineage. This parameter is only returned by the DescribeSnapshots API operation.

DiskImageSize.documentation: The size of the disk in the snapshot, in GiB.

Format.documentation: The format of the disk image from which the snapshot is created.

Url.documentation: The URL used to access the disk image.

UserBucket.documentation: The S3 bucket for the disk image.

DeviceName.documentation: The block device mapping for the snapshot.

SnapshotId.documentation: The snapshot ID of the disk being imported.

Progress.documentation: The percentage of progress for the task.

StatusMessage.documentation: A detailed status message for the snapshot creation.

Status.documentation: A brief status of the snapshot creation.

SnapshotDetail.documentation: Describes the snapshot created from the imported disk.

Description.documentation: The description of the disk image being imported.

Format.documentation:
The format of the disk image being imported.

Valid values: RAW | VHD | VMDK | OVA

Url.documentation: The URL to the Amazon S3-based disk image being imported. It can either be a https URL (https://..) or an Amazon S3 URL (s3://..).

UserBucket.documentation: The S3 bucket for the disk image.

SnapshotDiskContainer.documentation: The disk container object for the import snapshot request.

DiskImageSize.documentation: The size of the disk in the snapshot, in GiB.

Format.documentation: The format of the disk image from which the snapshot is created.

Url.documentation: The URL of the disk image from which the snapshot is created.

UserBucket.documentation: The S3 bucket for the disk image.

SnapshotId.documentation: The snapshot ID of the disk being imported.

Progress.documentation: The percentage of completion for the import snapshot task.

StatusMessage.documentation: A detailed status message for the import snapshot task.

Status.documentation: A brief status for the import snapshot task.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the account.

Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket where the Spot instance data feed is located.

Prefix.documentation: The prefix that is prepended to data feed files.

State.documentation: The state of the Spot instance data feed subscription.

Fault.documentation: The fault codes for the Spot instance request, if any.

SpotDatafeedSubscription.documentation: Describes the data feed for a Spot instance.

SecurityGroups.documentation: One or more security groups. When requesting instances in a VPC, you must specify the IDs of the security groups. When requesting instances in EC2-Classic, you can specify the names or the IDs of the security groups.

UserData.documentation: The user data to make available to the instances. If you are using an AWS SDK or command line tool, Base64-encoding is performed for you, and you can load the text from a file. Otherwise, you must provide Base64-encoded text.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: One or more block device mapping entries.

Monitoring.documentation: Enable or disable monitoring for the instances.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instances. To specify multiple subnets, separate them using commas; for example, "subnet-a61dafcf, subnet-65ea5f08".

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instances are optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

Default: false

WeightedCapacity.documentation:
The number of units provided by the specified instance type. These are the same units that you chose to set the target capacity in terms (instances or a performance characteristic such as vCPUs, memory, or I/O).

If the target capacity divided by this value is not a whole number, we round the number of instances to the next whole number. If this value is not specified, the default is 1.

SpotPrice.documentation: The bid price per unit hour for the specified instance type. If this value is not specified, the default is the Spot bid price specified for the fleet. To determine the bid price per unit hour, divide the Spot bid price by the value of WeightedCapacity.

SpotFleetLaunchSpecification.documentation: Describes the launch specification for one or more Spot instances.

SpotFleetRequestId.documentation: The ID of the Spot fleet request.

SpotFleetRequestState.documentation: The state of the Spot fleet request.

SpotFleetRequestConfig.documentation: Information about the configuration of the Spot fleet request.

CreateTime.documentation: The creation date and time of the request.

ActivityStatus.documentation: The progress of the Spot fleet request. If there is an error, the status is error. After all bids are placed, the status is pending_fulfillment. If the size of the fleet is equal to or greater than its target capacity, the status is fulfilled. If the size of the fleet is decreased, the status is pending_termination while Spot instances are terminating.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive identifier you provide to ensure idempotency of your listings. This helps avoid duplicate listings. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

TargetCapacity.documentation: The number of units to request. You can choose to set the target capacity in terms of instances or a performance characteristic that is important to your application workload, such as vCPUs, memory, or I/O.

ValidFrom.documentation: The start date and time of the request, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). The default is to start fulfilling the request immediately.

ValidUntil.documentation: The end date and time of the request, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). At this point, no new Spot instance requests are placed or enabled to fulfill the request.

TerminateInstancesWithExpiration.documentation: Indicates whether running Spot instances should be terminated when the Spot fleet request expires.

IamFleetRole.documentation: Grants the Spot fleet permission to terminate Spot instances on your behalf when you cancel its Spot fleet request using CancelSpotFleetRequests or when the Spot fleet request expires, if you set terminateInstancesWithExpiration.

LaunchSpecifications.documentation: Information about the launch specifications for the Spot fleet request.

ExcessCapacityTerminationPolicy.documentation: Indicates whether running Spot instances should be terminated if the target capacity of the Spot fleet request is decreased below the current size of the Spot fleet.

AllocationStrategy.documentation: Indicates how to allocate the target capacity across the Spot pools specified by the Spot fleet request. The default is lowestPrice.

FulfilledCapacity.documentation: The number of units fulfilled by this request compared to the set target capacity.

Type.documentation: The type of request. Indicates whether the fleet will only request the target capacity or also attempt to maintain it. When you request a certain target capacity, the fleet will only place the required bids. It will not attempt to replenish Spot instances if capacity is diminished, nor will it submit bids in alternative Spot pools if capacity is not available. When you want to maintain a certain target capacity, fleet will place the required bids to meet this target capacity. It will also automatically replenish any interrupted instances. Default: maintain.

SpotFleetRequestConfigData.documentation: Describes the configuration of a Spot fleet request.

SpotInstanceRequestId.documentation: The ID of the Spot instance request.

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum hourly price (bid) for the Spot instance launched to fulfill the request.

State.documentation: The state of the Spot instance request. Spot bid status information can help you track your Spot instance requests. For more information, see Spot Bid Status in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

Fault.documentation: The fault codes for the Spot instance request, if any.

Status.documentation: The status code and status message describing the Spot instance request.

ValidFrom.documentation: The start date of the request, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). The request becomes active at this date and time.

ValidUntil.documentation: The end date of the request, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). If this is a one-time request, it remains active until all instances launch, the request is canceled, or this date is reached. If the request is persistent, it remains active until it is canceled or this date is reached.

LaunchGroup.documentation: The instance launch group. Launch groups are Spot instances that launch together and terminate together.

AvailabilityZoneGroup.documentation: The Availability Zone group. If you specify the same Availability Zone group for all Spot instance requests, all Spot instances are launched in the same Availability Zone.

InstanceId.documentation: The instance ID, if an instance has been launched to fulfill the Spot instance request.

CreateTime.documentation: The date and time when the Spot instance request was created, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ).

ProductDescription.documentation: The product description associated with the Spot instance.

BlockDurationMinutes.documentation: The duration for the Spot instance, in minutes.

ActualBlockHourlyPrice.documentation: If you specified a duration and your Spot instance request was fulfilled, this is the fixed hourly price in effect for the Spot instance while it runs.

LaunchedAvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which the bid is launched.

Code.documentation: The reason code for the Spot instance state change.

Message.documentation: The message for the Spot instance state change.

Code.documentation: The status code. For a list of status codes, see Spot Bid Status Codes in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

UpdateTime.documentation: The date and time of the most recent status update, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ).

SpotInstanceStatus.documentation: Describes the status of a Spot instance request.

AvailabilityZone.documentation:
The Availability Zone.

[Spot fleet only] To specify multiple Availability Zones, separate them using commas; for example, "us-west-2a, us-west-2b".

GroupName.documentation: The name of the placement group (for cluster instances).

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum price (bid) that you are willing to pay for a Spot instance.

Timestamp.documentation: The date and time the request was created, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ).

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone.

SpotPrice.documentation: Describes the maximum hourly price (bid) for any Spot instance launched to fulfill the request.

FromPort.documentation: The start of the port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP type number. A value of -1 indicates all ICMP types.

IpProtocol.documentation: The IP protocol name (for tcp, udp, and icmp) or number (see Protocol Numbers).

IpRanges.documentation: One or more IP ranges. Not applicable for stale security group rules.

PrefixListIds.documentation: One or more prefix list IDs for an AWS service. Not applicable for stale security group rules.

ToPort.documentation: The end of the port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP type number. A value of -1 indicates all ICMP types.

UserIdGroupPairs.documentation: One or more security group pairs. Returns the ID of the referenced security group and VPC, and the ID and status of the VPC peering connection.

StaleIpPermission.documentation: Describes a stale rule in a security group.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC for the security group.

StaleIpPermissions.documentation: Information about the stale inbound rules in the security group.

StaleIpPermissionsEgress.documentation: Information about the stale outbound rules in the security group.

StaleSecurityGroup.documentation: Describes a stale security group (a security group that contains stale rules).

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

StartingInstances.documentation: Information about one or more started instances.

Code.documentation: The reason code for the state change.

Message.documentation:
The message for the state change.

  • Server.SpotInstanceTermination: A Spot instance was terminated due to an increase in the market price.

  • Server.InternalError: An internal error occurred during instance launch, resulting in termination.

  • Server.InsufficientInstanceCapacity: There was insufficient instance capacity to satisfy the launch request.

  • Client.InternalError: A client error caused the instance to terminate on launch.

  • Client.InstanceInitiatedShutdown: The instance was shut down using the shutdown -h command from the instance.

  • Client.UserInitiatedShutdown: The instance was shut down using the Amazon EC2 API.

  • Client.VolumeLimitExceeded: The limit on the number of EBS volumes or total storage was exceeded. Decrease usage or request an increase in your limits.

  • Client.InvalidSnapshot.NotFound: The specified snapshot was not found.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Force.documentation:
Forces the instances to stop. The instances do not have an opportunity to flush file system caches or file system metadata. If you use this option, you must perform file system check and repair procedures. This option is not recommended for Windows instances.

Default: false

StoppingInstances.documentation: Information about one or more stopped instances.

Storage.documentation: Describes the storage location for an instance store-backed AMI.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC the subnet is in.

CidrBlock.documentation: The CIDR block assigned to the subnet.

AvailableIpAddressCount.documentation: The number of unused IP addresses in the subnet. Note that the IP addresses for any stopped instances are considered unavailable.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone of the subnet.

DefaultForAz.documentation: Indicates whether this is the default subnet for the Availability Zone.

MapPublicIpOnLaunch.documentation: Indicates whether instances launched in this subnet receive a public IP address.

Key.documentation:
The key of the tag.

Constraints: Tag keys are case-sensitive and accept a maximum of 127 Unicode characters. May not begin with aws:

Value.documentation:
The value of the tag.

Constraints: Tag values are case-sensitive and accept a maximum of 255 Unicode characters.

ResourceId.documentation: The ID of the resource. For example, ami-1a2b3c4d.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

TerminatingInstances.documentation: Information about one or more terminated instances.

PrivateIpAddresses.documentation: The secondary private IP addresses to unassign from the network interface. You can specify this option multiple times to unassign more than one IP address.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

InstanceMonitorings.documentation: Monitoring information for one or more instances.

UnsuccessfulItem.documentation: Information about items that were not successfully processed in a batch call.

Message.documentation: The error message accompanying the error code.

UnsuccessfulItemError.documentation: Information about the error that occurred. For more information about errors, see Error Codes.

S3Bucket.documentation: The name of the S3 bucket where the disk image is located.

S3Key.documentation: The file name of the disk image.

UserBucket.documentation: Describes the S3 bucket for the disk image.

S3Bucket.documentation: The S3 bucket from which the disk image was created.

S3Key.documentation: The file name of the disk image.

UserBucketDetails.documentation: Describes the S3 bucket for the disk image.

Data.documentation: The user data. If you are using an AWS SDK or command line tool, Base64-encoding is performed for you, and you can load the text from a file. Otherwise, you must provide Base64-encoded text.

UserData.documentation: Describes the user data for an instance.

UserId.documentation:
The ID of an AWS account. For a referenced security group in another VPC, the account ID of the referenced security group is returned.

[EC2-Classic] Required when adding or removing rules that reference a security group in another AWS account.

GroupName.documentation: The name of the security group. In a request, use this parameter for a security group in EC2-Classic or a default VPC only. For a security group in a nondefault VPC, use the security group ID.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC for the referenced security group, if applicable.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of the VPC peering connection, if applicable.

PeeringStatus.documentation: The status of a VPC peering connection, if applicable.

UserIdGroupPair.documentation: Describes a security group and AWS account ID pair.

OutsideIpAddress.documentation: The Internet-routable IP address of the virtual private gateway's outside interface.

Status.documentation: The status of the VPN tunnel.

LastStatusChange.documentation: The date and time of the last change in status.

StatusMessage.documentation: If an error occurs, a description of the error.

Size.documentation: The size of the volume, in GiBs.

SnapshotId.documentation: The snapshot from which the volume was created, if applicable.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone for the volume.

CreateTime.documentation: The time stamp when volume creation was initiated.

VolumeType.documentation: The volume type. This can be gp2 for General Purpose SSD, io1 for Provisioned IOPS SSD, st1 for Throughput Optimized HDD, sc1 for Cold HDD, or standard for Magnetic volumes.

Iops.documentation:
The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) that the volume supports. For Provisioned IOPS SSD volumes, this represents the number of IOPS that are provisioned for the volume. For General Purpose SSD volumes, this represents the baseline performance of the volume and the rate at which the volume accumulates I/O credits for bursting. For more information on General Purpose SSD baseline performance, I/O credits, and bursting, see Amazon EBS Volume Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

Constraint: Range is 100-20000 IOPS for io1 volumes and 100-10000 IOPS for gp2 volumes.

Condition: This parameter is required for requests to create io1 volumes; it is not used in requests to create gp2, st1, sc1, or standard volumes.

Encrypted.documentation: Indicates whether the volume will be encrypted.

KmsKeyId.documentation: The full ARN of the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) that was used to protect the volume encryption key for the volume.

AttachTime.documentation: The time stamp when the attachment initiated.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the EBS volume is deleted on instance termination.

Size.documentation: The size of the volume, in GiB.

Code.documentation: The code identifying the operation, for example, enable-volume-io.

EventType.documentation: The event type associated with this operation.

EventId.documentation: The ID of the event associated with this operation.

Status.documentation: The intended status of the volume status.

NotBefore.documentation: The earliest start time of the event.

NotAfter.documentation: The latest end time of the event.

Status.documentation: The status of the volume.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone of the volume.

Events.documentation: A list of events associated with the volume.

DhcpOptionsId.documentation: The ID of the set of DHCP options you've associated with the VPC (or default if the default options are associated with the VPC).

InstanceTenancy.documentation: The allowed tenancy of instances launched into the VPC.

IsDefault.documentation: Indicates whether the VPC is the default VPC.

VpcAttachment.documentation: Describes an attachment between a virtual private gateway and a VPC.

ClassicLinkEnabled.documentation: Indicates whether the VPC is enabled for ClassicLink.

VpcClassicLink.documentation: Describes whether a VPC is enabled for ClassicLink.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC to which the endpoint is associated.

ServiceName.documentation: The name of the AWS service to which the endpoint is associated.

PolicyDocument.documentation: The policy document associated with the endpoint.

RouteTableIds.documentation: One or more route tables associated with the endpoint.

CreationTimestamp.documentation: The date and time the VPC endpoint was created.

AccepterVpcInfo.documentation: Information about the accepter VPC. CIDR block information is not returned when creating a VPC peering connection, or when describing a VPC peering connection that's in the initiating-request or pending-acceptance state.

ExpirationTime.documentation: The time that an unaccepted VPC peering connection will expire.

Status.documentation: The status of the VPC peering connection.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of the VPC peering connection.

AllowEgressFromLocalClassicLinkToRemoteV.documentation: Indicates whether a local ClassicLink connection can communicate with the peer VPC over the VPC peering connection.

AllowEgressFromLocalVpcToRemoteClassicLi.documentation: Indicates whether a local VPC can communicate with a ClassicLink connection in the peer VPC over the VPC peering connection.

AllowDnsResolutionFromRemoteVpc.documentation: Indicates whether a local VPC can resolve public DNS hostnames to private IP addresses when queried from instances in a peer VPC.

Code.documentation: The status of the VPC peering connection.

Message.documentation: A message that provides more information about the status, if applicable.

VpcPeeringConnectionStateReason.documentation: Describes the status of a VPC peering connection.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the VPC owner.

PeeringOptions.documentation: Information about the VPC peering connection options for the accepter or requester VPC.

VpcPeeringConnectionVpcInfo.documentation: Describes a VPC in a VPC peering connection.

State.documentation: The current state of the VPN connection.

CustomerGatewayConfiguration.documentation: The configuration information for the VPN connection's customer gateway (in the native XML format). This element is always present in the CreateVpnConnection response; however, it's present in the DescribeVpnConnections response only if the VPN connection is in the pending or available state.

CustomerGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the customer gateway at your end of the VPN connection.

VpnGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private gateway at the AWS side of the VPN connection.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the VPN connection.

Routes.documentation: The static routes associated with the VPN connection.

StaticRoutesOnly.documentation: Indicates whether the VPN connection uses static routes only. Static routes must be used for devices that don't support BGP.
Indicates whether the VPN connection uses static routes only. Static routes must be used for devices that don't support BGP.

VpnGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private gateway.

State.documentation: The current state of the virtual private gateway.

Type.documentation: The type of VPN connection the virtual private gateway supports.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone where the virtual private gateway was created, if applicable. This field may be empty or not returned.

VpcAttachments.documentation: Any VPCs attached to the virtual private gateway.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the virtual private gateway.

DestinationCidrBlock.documentation: The CIDR block associated with the local subnet of the customer data center.

State.documentation: The current state of the static route.

VpnStaticRoute.documentation: Describes a static route for a VPN connection.

documentation:
Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud

Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) provides resizable computing capacity in the Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud. Using Amazon EC2 eliminates your need to invest in hardware up front, so you can develop and deploy applications faster.
